data.title: Bonds climb on weak economic data, tariff turmoil; US10Y hits lowest since mid-December
data.description:
U.S. Treasury yields slid on Wednesday as Wall Street investors stepped in and bought bonds after some weak economic data on the services sector, disappointing earnings reports from Alphabet (GOOG)(GOOGL) and AMD (AMD) along with global jitters over tariffs.

The benchmark U.S. 10-Year Treasury yield (US10Y) fell as much as 9 basis points to 4.42%, a level not seen since mid-December 2024. The decline marks a key technical shift, as the yield previously held above the 4.50% support zone but has now broken below it. Additionally, the drop has pushed the yield below its 50-day moving average, signaling a potential change in market sentiment. See the chart below:

Earlier, S&P Global data showed weaker rises in both activity and new orders in the U.S. services sector in January. The business activity index fell to 52.9 from 56.8 in December 2024, wile the pace of output expansion slowed sharply and was the weakest since April last year. Notably, input prices further jumped in January and the rate of inflation reached a three-month high.

"Hopes of more rate cuts will be further diminished by the combination of increased hiring, reports of labor supply difficulties, and an upturn in price pressures," Chris Williamson, chief business economist at S&P Global Market Intelligence, said.

Meanwhile, another gauge on the U.S. services sector provided by the Institute for Supply Management (ISM) also showed a lower reading for January than December 2024.

"The ISM Services Index fell at the start of the year. While the index is still consistent with a broad expansion in activity that remains supportive of hiring, a pull back in new orders and only modest drop in prices paid show some lost momentum potentially stemming from apprehension around tariffs," Wells Fargo's Tim Quinlan said.

Tariffs remain at the top of global headlines following the U.S. and China's latest round of tit-for-tat duties on imported goods.

The shorter end U.S. 2-Year Treasury yield (US2Y) on Wednesday fell 5 basis points to 4.16%, a level also not seen since mid-December. Also, the longer-end U.S. 30-Year Treasury yield (US30Y) has slipped 9 basis points to 4.64%.

See how yields are trading across the curve here on Seeking Alpha’s bond page.

For investors looking to stay closely connected to the bond market, a more in-depth analysis of specific exchange-traded funds could prove valuable. Here are a few notable funds to consider:

Treasury ETFs: (TLT), (TLH), (IEF), (IEI), (SHY), (SGOV), (SCHO), and (BIL).

Bond ETFs: (AGG), (BND), (VCIT), (MUB), (MBB), (JNK), (LQD), (HYG), and (TIP).

data.title: Aurora sees 37% revenue growth in Q3 2025 driven by global medical cannabis expansion
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Aurora Cannabis Inc. (NASDAQ:ACB) Q3 2025

Management View

  • CEO Miguel Martin highlighted a "record third quarter for medical cannabis revenue, net income, adjusted EBITDA, and free cash flow." The company achieved a 37% increase in net revenue, largely driven by a 51% year-over-year growth in global medical cannabis. International revenue surged 112%, surpassing Canadian medical cannabis revenue for the second consecutive quarter and now contributing 60% of the global medical cannabis segment's net revenue.
  • Aurora's international markets, particularly Germany, Australia, Poland, and the UK, demonstrated strong performance, with Germany maintaining a leadership position. Martin emphasized the company’s focus on scaling its EU GMP and TGA GMP-certified facilities to support global demand.
  • CFO Simona King reported record net revenue of $88.2 million and a 316% increase in adjusted EBITDA to $23.1 million, marking the ninth consecutive quarter of positive adjusted EBITDA. The company ended the quarter with $180.2 million in cash and no cannabis business debt.
  • King added that adjusted gross margin for medical cannabis reached 74%, marking significant improvement due to higher-margin international markets and operational efficiencies.

Outlook

  • Management expects continued revenue growth across its global cannabis business, supported by year-over-year growth in Europe and Australia. Bevo's plant propagation segment is projected to benefit from seasonally higher revenues in the next quarter.
  • King indicated that margins are expected to remain strong, with positive adjusted EBITDA anticipated to persist. Free cash flow is projected to stay positive, driven by increased global medical cannabis sales and disciplined working capital management.
  • Martin reiterated the company’s focus on expanding its international footprint, emphasizing the scalability of Aurora's facilities and its ability to meet the growing global demand for medical cannabis.

Financial Results

  • Aurora’s Q3 2025 net revenue reached $88.2 million, surpassing analysts' estimates of $80.005 million. Adjusted EBITDA rose to a record $23.1 million, a significant improvement from $5.5 million in the year-ago period.
  • Global medical cannabis revenue hit $68.1 million, representing 77% of total net revenue. International medical cannabis revenue surged 112%, while Canadian medical cannabis grew 6% year-over-year.
  • Adjusted gross profit reached $56 million, supported by a consolidated adjusted gross margin of 65%. Medical cannabis gross margin rose to 74%, compared to 63% in the same quarter last year.
  • Bevo's plant propagation revenue increased 22% year-over-year to $8.9 million, with an adjusted gross margin improvement to 40%.
  • Aurora achieved $27 million in positive free cash flow and ended the quarter with $180.2 million in cash and cash equivalents.

Q&A

  • William Kirk, ROTH Capital Partners: "Are you running into any supply constraints, or do you still have room to meet growth opportunities?" Miguel Martin responded that Aurora feels confident in its supply capabilities, citing its EU GMP and TGA GMP-certified facilities as a competitive advantage.
  • Frederico Gomes, ATB Capital Markets: "How do you see competition impacting international medical cannabis markets?" Martin noted that competition is more consolidated internationally than in North America, with fewer but stronger competitors, particularly in high-regulation markets like Germany and Australia.
  • Derek Lessard, TD Cowen: "Can you provide insights into the sustainability of your 74% gross margin in medical cannabis?" Simona King attributed the strong margins to favorable pricing in international markets and operational efficiencies, adding that margins are expected to remain favorable in the coming quarters.

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts expressed a positive sentiment, focusing on the company’s strong international growth and profitability. Questions largely centered on the sustainability of margins and competitive positioning, indicating confidence in Aurora’s long-term strategy.
  • Management maintained a confident tone throughout the call, emphasizing record-breaking financial performance and growth prospects. Martin frequently highlighted Aurora's competitive advantages and scalability.
  • Compared to the previous quarter, management appeared more optimistic, especially given the record results and positive free cash flow.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • Net revenue grew from $81.1 million in Q2 to $88.2 million in Q3, supported by a stronger performance in international medical cannabis markets.
  • Adjusted EBITDA increased significantly from $10.1 million in Q2 to $23.1 million in Q3, reflecting higher gross profit and operational efficiencies.
  • International revenue now accounts for 60% of global medical cannabis net revenue, up from 57% in the previous quarter, showcasing continued momentum in markets like Germany and Australia.
  • Management’s tone in Q3 was notably more upbeat, driven by record-setting financial metrics and a strong cash position.

Risks and Concerns

  • Management acknowledged the potential challenges of navigating regulatory complexities in international markets, particularly in Germany, Poland, and Australia.
  • Analysts raised concerns about potential pricing impacts from increased competition in global medical cannabis markets. Martin emphasized Aurora’s competitive advantages, including regulatory expertise and localized production capabilities.
  • Seasonal fluctuations in Bevo’s plant propagation business remain a factor, though the segment is expected to deliver higher revenues in the next quarter.

Final Takeaway

Aurora Cannabis delivered a record-breaking quarter, with strong growth in international medical cannabis markets driving a 37% increase in net revenue. Management’s focus on operational excellence, margin expansion, and a medical-first strategy has positioned the company as a leader in high-margin global markets. With a robust cash position, no cannabis business debt, and a scalable operational footprint, Aurora is well-positioned to capitalize on future opportunities and deliver sustainable growth.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: Prudential projects 5%-8% EPS growth through 2027 with $1B share repurchase plan for 2025
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Prudential Financial (NYSE:PRU) Q4 2024

Management View

  • CEO Charlie Lowrey announced significant leadership changes, including Andy Sullivan as the next CEO and Caroline Feeney taking on an expanded role overseeing Global Retirement and Insurance businesses. Jacques Chappuis will join as CEO of PGIM.
  • Lowrey highlighted strategic progress, including a 60% reduction in guaranteed universal life exposure through two reinsurance transactions and a $7 billion Japanese whole life policy reinsurance deal via Prismic.
  • CFO Yanela Frias emphasized the company’s robust liquidity position, with $4.6 billion in highly liquid assets, and discussed the Board's authorization for up to $1 billion in share repurchases for 2025.

Outlook

  • Management introduced financial targets through 2027, projecting annual core EPS growth of 5%-8% and an adjusted ROE of 13%-15%.
  • CFO Frias shared plans for an operating expense ratio of 8.5%-10.5% for Global Retirement and Insurance businesses, expected to trend downward over the three-year period.
  • Prudential expects 30%-40% of capital deployment towards organic growth, while maintaining a free cash flow ratio of approximately 65% of net income, with 35%-45% allocated to dividends.

Financial Results

  • Q4 pre-tax adjusted operating income was $1.4 billion, translating to $2.96 per share, with full-year 2024 adjusted operating income at $5.9 billion or $12.62 per share, a 6% increase from 2023.
  • PGIM reported $1.4 trillion in assets under management, supported by $8.6 billion in quarterly net flows and strong investment performance.
  • Retirement Strategies achieved its highest institutional pension risk transfer sales since 2012, with $36 billion in annual sales, up 27% year-over-year. Individual Retirement sales exceeded $14 billion, marking an 84% increase.
  • International businesses saw a 14% increase in Japan’s retirement and savings product sales and 12% growth in Brazil.

Q&A

  • Suneet Kamath, Jefferies: Questioned sustainability of high annuity sales given industry trends. Head of U.S. Businesses Caroline Feeney highlighted a diversified product portfolio and strong tailwinds from aging demographics and money in motion, including $70 billion in fixed annuities maturing and $7 trillion in money market funds.
  • Ryan Krueger, KBW: Asked about capital usage freed by reinsurance deals. CFO Frias reiterated disciplined capital deployment and flexibility for organic growth, dividends, and share repurchases.
  • Elyse Greenspan, Wells Fargo: Clarified growth expectations for 2025 relative to the 5%-8% target. CFO Frias noted near-term headwinds but emphasized confidence in upward trajectory over the three-year period.

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts appeared focused on capital deployment strategies, potential headwinds in Japan, and sustainability of high annuity sales. Their tone was neutral to slightly positive.
  • Management maintained confidence during prepared remarks but adopted a more cautious tone in addressing headwinds, particularly in Japan’s surrender activity and near-term growth moderation.
  • Compared to the previous quarter, management’s sentiment was slightly more defensive, especially when discussing new regulatory impacts in Japan.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • Q4 operating income of $1.4 billion declined from Q3’s $1.6 billion due to adverse underwriting results and elevated large individual life claims.
  • Q4 International business sales grew 6% year-over-year, compared to a 25% growth rate in Q3. Japan’s surrender activity continued to weigh on earnings, though Q4 saw the lowest surrender levels of 2024.
  • Management tone was slightly more cautious this quarter, reflecting headwinds in Japan and regulatory uncertainties.

Risks and Concerns

  • Elevated surrender rates in Japan driven by yen weakness impacted earnings. Management is addressing this through product diversification and reinsurance transactions.
  • Regulatory changes in Japan’s ESR regime are expected to introduce challenges for long-duration and foreign-currency-denominated products, prompting proactive reinsurance solutions.
  • Analysts raised concerns about sustaining high annuity sales amid potential industry-wide slowdowns and the impact of excess mortality.

Final Takeaway

Prudential Financial highlighted significant leadership transitions and strategic initiatives to drive growth, including the introduction of new financial targets through 2027 and a $1 billion share repurchase plan for 2025. While headwinds such as elevated Japan surrenders and regulatory changes remain, the company is leveraging product diversification, disciplined capital deployment, and robust liquidity to position itself for long-term growth.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: BlackRock said to launch bitcoin ETP in Europe after IBIT success
data.description:
Building on the success of its U.S.-listed iShares Bitcoin Trust (IBIT), BlackRock (NYSE:BLK) is gearing up to list a bitcoin (BTC-USD) exchange-traded product in Europe, according to a media report dated Wednesday.

That would be the asset manager's first crypto-tied ETP not traded on U.S. exchanges.

The new fund tied directly to bitcoin (BTC-USD) is expected to be domiciled in Switzerland, Bloomberg reported, citing people familiar with the plans. Marketing for the fund could start as soon as this month, one person noted.

The move comes a year after the debut of BlackRock's (NYSE:BLK) iShares Bitcoin Trust (IBIT), along with several other spot bitcoin ETFs. Demand for the products surged in the wake of a crypto-market bull run, with $58B IBIT leading the group in assets under management.

Last month, BlackRock's (BLK) ETF chief, Samara Cohen, told CNBC in an interview that there will "absolutely" be better clarity on crypto regulation this year.

data.title: Commencement Bancorp announces share buyback
data.description:
• Commencement Bancorp (OTCQX:CBWA) has announced share repurchase program commencing from February 5, 2025, and expiring February 4, 2026. 
  • Source: Press Release

data.title: UnitedHealth contacts SEC after Bill Ackman since-deleted post - report
data.description:
UnitedHealth (NYSE:UNH) has contacted the US Securities and Exchange Commission about its issues with hedge fund investor Bill Ackman's since-deleted post on X. Shares of UnitedHealth fell 2.3% in the wake of the Ackman posting.

“Health insurance has long been subject to significant regulatory oversight and earnings caps,” UnitedHealth said in a statement to Bloomberg. The company added that claims that insurers “can somehow over-earn are grossly uninformed.”

A representative for Ackman had no immediate comment for Bloomberg.

data.title: Nuvectis Pharma announces pricing of $13.5M public offering
data.description:
• Nuvectis Pharma (NASDAQ:NVCT) on Wednesday announced the pricing of its underwritten public offering of 2.7 million shares of its common stock at a price of $5.00 per share, with expected gross proceeds to Nuvectis of $13.5 million.
  • Nuvectis has also granted the underwriter a 30-day option to purchase up to 405,000 additional shares of its common stock at the public offering price.
  • The offering is expected to close on February 6, 2025.
  • Nuvectis intends to use the net proceeds from the offering to continue to advance the development programs of NXP800 and NXP900 or any future product candidate, hiring of additional personnel, capital expenditures, costs of operating as a public company and other general corporate purposes.
  • NVCT is +6.14% to $7.43.
  • Source: Press Release

data.title: Datasea sees Q2 revenue rising 81% to $20.5 million
data.description:
• Datasea (NASDAQ:DTSS) said on Wednesday that its revenue for Q2 FY25 is expected to be about $20.5 million, representing an 81% increase compared to $11.3 million for the year-ago period.
  • Gross profit for the second quarter is estimated to be $0.41 million, a 310% increase from $0.1 million for the year-ago period.
  • The expected rise in metrics was driven by the continued high growth of the company's 5G AI multimodal digital business and its increased market penetration across China, the company said.
  • DTSS is -2.81% to $2.0701
  • Source: Press Release

data.title: Fiserv targets 10%-12% organic revenue growth in 2025 with $5.5B free cash flow projection
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Fiserv (NYSE:FI) Q4 2024

Management View

  • Fiserv reported adjusted EPS of $2.51 for Q4 2024, a 15% increase, with adjusted operating margins reaching 42.9%. Organic revenue growth was 13%, driven by double-digit growth in the Merchant segment.
  • CEO Frank Bisignano highlighted the company’s achievements in exceeding commitments set during the 2023 Investor Conference. Free cash flow for the year was $5.2 billion, with $5.5 billion returned to shareholders through share repurchases.
  • The company launched CashFlow Central, which aims to address challenges in SMB cash flow management. Demand from financial institutions remains high, and the product is set to integrate with the broader SMB suite later this year.
  • Fiserv expanded its global reach with launches in three new countries for Clover: Brazil, Mexico, and Australia. The company also signed a strategic partnership with ADP to integrate payroll and business management solutions into Clover.
  • Mike Lyons, the newly appointed President and next CEO, emphasized his excitement for Fiserv’s growth opportunities and reaffirmed the company’s focus on executing its strategic plan.
  • CFO Bob Hau reported, "Total company adjusted revenue grew 7% for the quarter, with adjusted operating income growth of 11%."

Outlook

  • Fiserv provided 2025 guidance of 10%-12% organic revenue growth, over 125 basis points of adjusted operating margin expansion, and 15%-17% adjusted EPS growth. Free cash flow is projected at approximately $5.5 billion.
  • Merchant Solutions is expected to grow organically by 12%-15%, supported by Clover’s $3.5 billion revenue target for 2025 and further VAS penetration.
  • Financial Solutions is forecasted to grow organically by 6%-8%, driven by new product rollouts, including CashFlow Central, and key client wins such as Target and Verizon.
  • Management noted that growth in 2025 would be weighted towards the second half due to product rollouts and new client implementations.

Financial Results

  • Adjusted EPS of $2.51 for Q4 2024 exceeded the analysts' estimate of $2.48. Adjusted revenue of $4.96 billion slightly surpassed the $4.95 billion estimate.
  • Full-year adjusted EPS reached $8.80, up 17%, and total company organic revenue growth was 16%.
  • Merchant Solutions saw 23% organic revenue growth in Q4, with Clover revenue growing 29% to $2.7 billion for the year. The segment's adjusted operating margin expanded 290 basis points to 37% in 2024.
  • Financial Solutions grew organically by 4% in Q4 and 6% for the year, with strong contributions from digital payments products and issuing.

Q&A

  • Tien-Tsin Huang, JPMorgan: Asked about surprises for Mike Lyons upon joining Fiserv. Mike Lyons noted the vast potential in cross-selling opportunities, international expansion, and the innovation-driven team.
  • Darrin Peller, Wolfe Research: Inquired about sustaining Clover’s growth. CEO Bisignano highlighted international expansion, new hardware launches, and deep integration with partners like ADP as key drivers.
  • Timothy Chiodo, UBS: Asked about the Payfare acquisition and its role in embedded finance. CFO Hau stated that Payfare enhances program management capabilities and supports Fiserv’s embedded finance pipeline.
  • Ramsey El-Assal, Barclays: Questioned the timeline for CashFlow Central's material impact. CEO Bisignano indicated revenue contributions would begin in late 2025, with significant growth expected in 2026.

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts expressed optimism regarding Clover's growth potential and the company’s ability to execute on its strategic priorities. Questions focused on sustaining momentum and leveraging new opportunities.
  • Management maintained a confident tone, particularly around 2025 guidance and the SMB suite. CEO Bisignano emphasized the durability of Fiserv’s growth drivers with statements like "all gas and no break."
  • Compared to the previous quarter, there was a stronger focus from analysts on the sustainability of margins and revenue growth in challenging markets.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • Q4 organic revenue growth of 13% slightly decelerated from 15% in Q3 due to easing Argentina-related tailwinds. Adjusted EPS growth remained consistent at 15%.
  • Merchant Solutions growth slowed marginally from 24% in Q3 to 23% in Q4, though Clover’s revenue growth held steady at 29%.
  • Financial Solutions showed stable organic growth of 4% in Q4, in line with Q3 performance.
  • Management’s tone during prepared remarks remained consistent, with confidence in product rollouts and partnerships. Analysts continued to press for details on margin sustainability and growth pacing into 2025.

Risks and Concerns

  • Management highlighted the ongoing stabilization of Argentina’s economy, which could diminish transitory benefits in 2025.
  • Analysts raised concerns about consumer spending trends impacting volume growth in Clover and enterprise segments.
  • Competition in embedded finance and international markets could pressure growth targets. Management is mitigating risks with new partnerships and product differentiation.

Final Takeaway

Fiserv showcased strong financial performance in Q4 2024, demonstrating growth in its Merchant and Financial Solutions segments. The company is focused on executing its strategic priorities, including international expansion and the rollout of CashFlow Central, with 2025 guidance signaling confidence in sustained growth. The leadership transition to Mike Lyons appears seamless, with management emphasizing innovation and operational excellence to drive shareholder value.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: Philip Morris’ smoke-free products in focus during Q4 earnings
data.description:
Philip Morris (NYSE:PM) is set to report fourth quarter earnings on Thursday, and investors’ focus will be on the global tobacco giant’s smoke-free products (SFPs) business as health-conscious consumers switch to alternatives.

Wall Street expects the company to report EPS of $1.50, implying an increase of 10.3%, while revenue is expected to rise 4.3% to $9.44 billion during the quarter.

Philip Morris has witnessed high growth for its SFPs as Zyn nicotine pouch accounts for 72% share of oral or nicotine pouch category in the U.S. The Food and Drug Administration (FDA), in January, also authorized the marketing of 20 Zyn products through the premarket tobacco product application pathway.

Morgan Stanley analyst Eric Serotta said SFPs accounted for about 38% of PMI's net revenue in 2024e, and forecast SFPs to reach 55-65% by 2030e.

Serotta added we estimate that Zyn revenues in the U.S. could increase two-three times by 2030 driven by robust growth for the modern oral category and increased capacity following this year's supply constraints.

However, the company could face some foreign exchange (FX) headwinds due to the recent strengthening of the U.S. dollar, said analysts.

Meanwhile, overall combustible volumes have been essentially flat in 2024 following a 1.2% decline in 2023.

Analysts estimate a more normal rate of combustible decline in 2025, down over 1.5%. However, Philip Morris’ strong pricing of cigarettes could offset the impact of volume decline.

The tobacco company also plans to continue to roll out several new IQOS, a line of heated tobacco and electronic cigarette products.

Seeking Alpha analyst Skeptical12 said the company is also planning to be able to sell IQOS ILUMA in the US in the back half of this year as well, after recently introducing IQOS technology on a limited basis in the US in 2024, with an aim to capture 10% market share of the US tobacco and reduced risk market by 2030.

Wall Street, Seeking Alpha analysts and Seeking Alpha's Quant Ratings are bullish and rated the stock a Buy.

Over the last two years, PM has beaten EPS estimates 88% of the time and has beaten revenue estimates 75% of the time.

Over the last three months, EPS estimates have seen one upward revision versus six downward moves, while revenue estimates have seen no upward revisions compared to five downward moves.

Philip Morris’ shares jumped over 43% in the last one year, outperforming the broader S&P market, which gained nearly 22%.
